awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing eco-evolutionary trophic cascades in aquatic ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
Changes to predator communities are occurring on a global scale. Because top predators can exert strong pressures on other species in a community, it is important to understand the consequences of their losses or gains. Will re-introduction of wolves alter current elk or moose populations? Will the loss of marine predators cause fish communities to collapse? These expectations often generate controversy. This project tests how evolutionary responses of prey to their predators might alter commonly-expected results of cascading effects within food chains. Predation, trophic cascades, and evolution are features of all natural ecosystems. Understanding how these processes interact is fundamental to interpreting past ecosystem changes and to predicting future changes. The results from this study will directly inform many of the controversies attending management of large predators. High school teachers and undergraduate students with teaching aspirations will be introduced to the ecological relevance of evolution through hands-on involvement in the research. This teacher training program will target teachers and students from traditionally underrepresented groups who work, or plan to work, in high needs schools with diverse and underprivileged students. 

The study of eco-evolutionary dynamics considers how ongoing evolution interacts with ecological interactions to shape population, community and ecosystem processes. Intriguing case studies suggest the effects of contemporary evolution on ecology can be large, but this area of research lacks theory that would extend its general importance. This research serves as a potential general application of the broader synthetic theory of eco-evolutionary dynamics through study of trophic cascades. It will provide an initial test of the requisite conditions of eco-evolutionary trophic cascades and quantitatively compare the magnitude and pattern of their effects to those of classical density- and behaviorally-mediated trophic cascades to understand their importance. Field surveys, manipulative experiments, and common garden experiments will be integrated to test the following predictions: 1) prey feeding traits in wild populations differ predictably in response to predator presence or absence, 2) feeding trait differences are heritable, 3) heritable differences in prey traits affect the density and species composition of prey resources, and 4) effects on prey resources cascade down food chains to influence  primary producers. These conditions will be tested using recently introduced populations of Western mosquitofish inhabiting ponds with or without predatory largemouth bass. Mosquitofish are a classic system for studying both trophic cascades and contemporary evolution, and preliminary evidence supports evolutionary trade-offs between predator avoidance and resource competition. Numerous wild populations, small body size, short life span, and easy husbandry make this species well suited for the combined field and laboratory assays required for this research.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the ecological relevance of ongoing evolution (contemporary evolution) is an important research goal at the intersection of ecology and evolution. Consistent with this goal, we proposed a general theory of eco-evolutionary trophic cascades (Figure 1). The collaborative research in this project provided a direct test of this theory using the Western Mosquitofish (Gambusia affinis) as a model system.  The major goals of the project were to 1) rigorously test the impact of mosquitofish trait variation on the strength of trophic cascades, and 2) to provide important context by quantitatively assessing the strength of evolutionary effects relative to other factors like population density.  In the process, we also sought to develop new quantitative theory to generalize our work to other systems.

In a collaborative effort with University of California Santa Cruz colleagues we collected and compared mosquitofish from over two dozen wild populations in California, USA. These populations spanned habitats with and without largemouth bass (Micropterus salmoides), an important predator of mosquitofish.   We hypothesized that presence of such predators would shape mosquitofish traits (morphology, behavior, life  history) in ways that tip the balance between predator defense and competitive foraging, shaping ecological outcomes in other trophic levels.  In addition to comparing trait patterns in wild populations, we also conducted common environment rearing studies on about half of these populations to ascertain the heritable (evolutionary) basis for mosquitofish trait variation, along with a series of mesocosm (artificial pond system ? Figure 2) experiments to quantify how mosquitofish trait variation affects other trophic levels (e.g., bass growth, zooplankton community structure, algal production).

Our modeling of eco-evolutionary trophic cascades suggested that the predominant outcome of including evolution of a focal species, like mosquitofish, is to mediate or substitute for the relative effects of classic density-mediated trophic cascades. This does not mean such eco-evolutionary effects are inconsequential, just they can be difficult to discern without focused research (i.e., cryptic)(Figure 3). Comparisons of wild populations supported that presence or absence of predators can shape mosquitofish traits affecting predator defense and foraging competitiveness.  Common rearing of these populations showed that some trait variation reflected shared patterns of evolution, but the largest component of evolutionary variation was often unique to populations within predator backgrounds. Nonetheless, our mesocosm studies consistently showed that mosquitofish from different predator backgrounds produced distinctly different community responses, shaping the growth rates of their predators and restructuring zooplankton communities.  In some cases, these trait effects were nearly as large as those of mosquitofish density.

Broadly speaking, our findings supported our overarching hypothesis, with the interesting nuance that locally idiosyncratic adaptations may be a very important contribution to eco-evolutionary dynamics in mosquitofish, and possibly other systems.  This led us to develop some new theory on ?eco-evolutionary potential? in interacting networks that may help the field develop more generalized eco-evo predictions despite locally idiosyncratic adaptations.

Our research also revealed insights that are apt to be valuable to the broader field of ecology and other disciplines.  For example, we applied our eco-evolutionary trophic cascades simulation model to harvest fisheries and found that harvest of top predators is expected to generate significant evolution in lower trophic levels and that feedbacks from this evolution can dramatically change the predictions for harvest outcomes from sustainability to fisheries collapse.  In one of our mesocosm studies we discovered that female mosquitofish have much stronger effects on their associated communities than male mosquitofish, to the point that natural sex ratio variation maybe an important determinant of community structure and ecosystem function in nature. In another one of our mesocosm experiments we included domesticated mosquitofish and found that they not only show a strange amalgam of traits patterns found in wild populations, but also shape their communities differently. This suggests a possible implication for restoration biology in that fish supplementation programs might not be providing the surrogate ecosystem services they intend.

In total, our collaborative research project generated over 22 peer reviewed publications, trained three University of Maine graduate students, and provided research experiences for more than a dozen undergraduate students.  This work also led to the development of new fish rearing capacity at the University of Maine to enable future mosquitofish research, strengthened research collaborations with the University of California Santa Cruz, and fostered new collaborations with investigators at other universities in the United States and abroad (i.e., New Zealand).  Capacity developed during the conduct of this project helped the PI to obtain over $25 million in additional research funds that now support over 30 additional researchers and graduate students across Maine, a state that has traditionally lagged other states in research activity.

We suggest that our research provides a concrete pedagogical example of why evolutionary principles are important and relevant to understanding and addressing ecological challenges that face society today, including challenges surrounding invasive species, harvest sustainability, and resource restoration.
